title: Supermarket Navigation
en: Supermarkets are divided into sections like fruit, vegetables, meat, dairy, and frozen food. Signs above aisles help you find items. For example: The dairy section is in aisle 3. This can be found in most large supermarkets.

title: Reading Aisle Signs
en: Aisle signs list the main items available in each row to help you navigate. For example: Aisle 5: bread, rice, pasta. Common in large chain supermarkets.

title: Checking Price Labels
en: Price labels are located on the shelf under each product. For example: Milk: $2.50 per litre. Always check the shelf label, not just the packaging.

title: Understanding Unit Price
en: The unit price shows cost per 100g or per kg, making it easier to compare products. For example: Rice: $3.00/kg. Unit price helps find the best value.

title: Special Offers
en: Discounts and specials are often highlighted with bright tags. For example: Buy 2 for $5. Check expiry dates when buying specials.

title: Using Trolleys and Baskets
en: Trolleys and baskets are provided at the entrance for carrying items. For example: Take a trolley for a big shop. Return trolleys to designated areas.

title: Queuing at Checkout
en: Always line up and wait for your turn at the cashier. For example: Please wait behind the line. Queueing is important etiquette in Australia.

title: Self-Checkout Machines
en: Self-checkout allows you to scan and pay for items yourself. For example: Scan the barcode and follow screen instructions. Staff can assist if needed.

title: Payment Methods
en: You can pay by cash, card, or contactless (tap). For example: Tap your card to pay. Contactless payment is widely used.

title: Bagging Groceries
en: Bring reusable bags or buy bags at checkout. For example: Plastic bags cost 15 cents. Reusable bags help reduce waste.

title: Checking Expiry Dates
en: Always check expiry dates on perishable items before buying. For example: Milk expires on 12 March. Important for dairy and meat.

title: Fresh Food Sections
en: Supermarkets often have bakery, deli, and butcher sections. For example: Get fresh bread from the bakery section. These sections sell fresh, daily-made food.

title: Asking Staff for Help
en: Staff can help you find items if you cannot locate them. For example: Excuse me, where is the rice? Staff usually wear uniforms.

title: Loyalty Cards
en: Some supermarkets offer loyalty cards to collect points. For example: Use Flybuys card for discounts. Points can give rewards or vouchers.

title: Opening Hours
en: Most supermarkets open from 7am to 9pm. For example: Coles closes at 9pm. Some are open 24 hours.

title: Weighing Produce
en: Some fruits and vegetables need to be weighed before checkout. For example: Weigh apples at the scale. Not all supermarkets require this.

title: Storage Advice
en: Labels may include storage advice for fresh food. For example: Keep refrigerated at 4°C. Follow advice to keep food safe.

title: Halal/Kosher/Vegetarian Products
en: Special sections may stock halal, kosher, or vegetarian food. For example: This aisle has halal meat. Labels help identify dietary needs.

title: Weekend Crowds
en: Supermarkets are busiest on weekends. For example: Saturday morning is very crowded. Shop on weekdays to avoid crowds.

title: Returning Items
en: You can return faulty items with a receipt. For example: Return milk that has spoiled before expiry. Policies may vary by store.
